findings.title: Hardcoded API Key Exposure Risk in Documentation
findings.description: The skill documentation contains multiple examples showing 'YOUR_API_KEY' placeholders and instructs users to set MATON_API_KEY as an environment variable. While the examples use placeholders, the skill's reliance on a third-party API gateway (maton.ai) for OAuth token management creates a credential exposure risk. All Slack API requests are proxied through gateway.maton.ai with the user's API key, meaning the gateway has access to both the Maton API key and the OAuth tokens for Slack workspaces. This creates a single point of failure where compromise of the gateway or API key leads to full Slack workspace access.
findings.snippet:
```bash
export MATON_API_KEY="YOUR_API_KEY"
```
All requests require: `Authorization: Bearer YOUR_API_KEY`
Base URL: `https://gateway.maton.ai/slack/{method}`
findings.remediation: 1. Implement secure credential storage using system keychains or encrypted vaults instead of environment variables. 2. Add warnings about the security implications of using a third-party OAuth proxy. 3. Consider implementing direct Slack OAuth instead of relying on an external gateway. 4. Document the trust model clearly - users must trust maton.ai with full Slack workspace access. 5. Implement API key rotation mechanisms and document best practices.

metadata.overall_assessment: This Slack integration skill presents SIGNIFICANT SECURITY CONCERNS due to its architecture of routing all Slack API requests through a third-party gateway (maton.ai). The primary risks are: (1) Data exfiltration - all Slack workspace data flows through an external service with no visibility into logging or storage practices, (2) Credential exposure - the gateway has persistent access to OAuth tokens and can perform any Slack operation, (3) Misleading description - the skill appears to be a standard Slack integration but actually introduces a third-party intermediary with full workspace access. Additional concerns include hardcoded API key patterns in documentation, a missing referenced Python file (Slack.py), and lack of transparency about the trust model. While the skill may be functional, the security implications of using a third-party OAuth proxy for enterprise Slack workspaces are severe. The skill is NOT RECOMMENDED for production use without significant security enhancements and clear disclosure of the proxy architecture.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The documentation clearly shows API key requirement. While the examples use placeholders (not hardcoded secrets), the architectural dependency on a third-party API key is a real security concern.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Medium - Requires API key compromise, but key is used in every request
metadata.meta_impact: High - Compromised API key grants access to all connected Slack workspaces

findings.title: Third-Party OAuth Proxy Creates Data Exfiltration Risk
findings.description: The skill routes all Slack API requests through a third-party gateway (gateway.maton.ai) that 'automatically injects your OAuth token'. This architecture means all Slack workspace data (messages, channels, users, files) flows through an external service controlled by maton.ai. Users have no visibility into what data the gateway logs, stores, or transmits. The gateway has persistent access to OAuth tokens and can perform any Slack API operation on behalf of the user. This creates significant data exfiltration and privacy risks, especially for enterprise Slack workspaces containing sensitive business communications.
findings.snippet:
Base URL: `https://gateway.maton.ai/slack/{method}`
'The gateway proxies requests to slack.com and automatically injects your OAuth token.'
All API calls go through: POST 'https://gateway.maton.ai/slack/api/chat.postMessage'
findings.remediation: 1. Implement direct Slack OAuth without third-party proxies for production use. 2. Add prominent security warnings about data flowing through external services. 3. Document what data maton.ai collects, stores, and how long it's retained. 4. Provide alternative implementation using direct Slack API with user-managed OAuth. 5. Implement end-to-end encryption if proxy architecture is required. 6. Add audit logging of all gateway requests.

metadata.overall_assessment: This Slack integration skill presents SIGNIFICANT SECURITY CONCERNS due to its architecture of routing all Slack API requests through a third-party gateway (maton.ai). The primary risks are: (1) Data exfiltration - all Slack workspace data flows through an external service with no visibility into logging or storage practices, (2) Credential exposure - the gateway has persistent access to OAuth tokens and can perform any Slack operation, (3) Misleading description - the skill appears to be a standard Slack integration but actually introduces a third-party intermediary with full workspace access. Additional concerns include hardcoded API key patterns in documentation, a missing referenced Python file (Slack.py), and lack of transparency about the trust model. While the skill may be functional, the security implications of using a third-party OAuth proxy for enterprise Slack workspaces are severe. The skill is NOT RECOMMENDED for production use without significant security enhancements and clear disclosure of the proxy architecture.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: LLM analyzer correctly identified the architectural risk. The skill documentation explicitly states all requests go through gateway.maton.ai with automatic OAuth token injection. This is a fundamental design issue, not a false positive.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Easy - Users unknowingly grant full Slack workspace access to third party by using this skill
metadata.meta_impact: Critical - Complete access to all Slack workspace data (messages, files, users, channels) by external service

findings.title: Misleading Skill Description Omits Third-Party Dependency
findings.description: The skill description states 'Slack API integration with managed OAuth' but fails to clearly disclose that this is not a direct Slack integration. Instead, all API requests are proxied through a third-party service (maton.ai) that manages OAuth tokens on behalf of users. The description makes it sound like a standard Slack integration, but the architecture introduces significant trust assumptions and security implications that are not apparent from the description alone. Users may not realize they're granting a third party full access to their Slack workspace.
findings.snippet:
Description: 'Slack API integration with managed OAuth. Send messages, manage channels, search conversations, and interact with Slack workspaces.'
Actual implementation: All requests proxied through https://gateway.maton.ai with third-party OAuth token management
findings.remediation: 1. Update description to clearly state: 'Third-party Slack API proxy via maton.ai gateway with managed OAuth'. 2. Add prominent disclaimer about data flowing through external services. 3. Document the trust model and security implications upfront. 4. Provide comparison with direct Slack OAuth approach. 5. Add section on data privacy and third-party access.

metadata.overall_assessment: This Slack integration skill presents SIGNIFICANT SECURITY CONCERNS due to its architecture of routing all Slack API requests through a third-party gateway (maton.ai). The primary risks are: (1) Data exfiltration - all Slack workspace data flows through an external service with no visibility into logging or storage practices, (2) Credential exposure - the gateway has persistent access to OAuth tokens and can perform any Slack operation, (3) Misleading description - the skill appears to be a standard Slack integration but actually introduces a third-party intermediary with full workspace access. Additional concerns include hardcoded API key patterns in documentation, a missing referenced Python file (Slack.py), and lack of transparency about the trust model. While the skill may be functional, the security implications of using a third-party OAuth proxy for enterprise Slack workspaces are severe. The skill is NOT RECOMMENDED for production use without significant security enhancements and clear disclosure of the proxy architecture.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The description objectively omits critical information about the proxy architecture. This is not a false positive - users cannot make informed security decisions without knowing their data flows through a third party.
metadata.meta_exploitability: Easy - Users unknowingly trust third party due to incomplete disclosure
metadata.meta_impact: High - Users grant access without understanding security implications

findings.title: Missing Referenced Script File Creates Tool Execution Risk
findings.description: The skill instructions reference a file 'Slack.py' that is not found in the package. This creates ambiguity about how the skill is intended to be used. If users attempt to locate or create this missing file, they may introduce security vulnerabilities. The missing file could also indicate incomplete packaging, supply chain issues, or that the skill relies on external dependencies not included in the package. Without the actual implementation, it's impossible to verify what operations the Python script performs or whether it properly validates inputs.
findings.snippet:
Referenced Files: Slack.py (not found)
No script files found in package, but instructions reference Python implementation
findings.remediation: 1. Include all referenced files in the skill package. 2. If Slack.py is optional, document this clearly and explain when it's needed. 3. If the skill is documentation-only (no scripts), update the description to clarify this. 4. Provide the complete implementation or remove references to missing files. 5. Add integrity checks to verify all required files are present.

metadata.overall_assessment: This Slack integration skill presents SIGNIFICANT SECURITY CONCERNS due to its architecture of routing all Slack API requests through a third-party gateway (maton.ai). The primary risks are: (1) Data exfiltration - all Slack workspace data flows through an external service with no visibility into logging or storage practices, (2) Credential exposure - the gateway has persistent access to OAuth tokens and can perform any Slack operation, (3) Misleading description - the skill appears to be a standard Slack integration but actually introduces a third-party intermediary with full workspace access. Additional concerns include hardcoded API key patterns in documentation, a missing referenced Python file (Slack.py), and lack of transparency about the trust model. While the skill may be functional, the security implications of using a third-party OAuth proxy for enterprise Slack workspaces are severe. The skill is NOT RECOMMENDED for production use without significant security enhancements and clear disclosure of the proxy architecture.
metadata.meta_confidence_reason: The missing file is concerning from a completeness perspective, but the skill appears functional without it (all examples use curl). This is more of a packaging issue than a security threat.
metadata.meta_impact: Low - May cause confusion but skill works without the file
